What of the wind that has the balloon just out-of-reach for the girl? It is change. The girl (people) is (are) reaching (hope/hoping) out for the balloon (love (and heart)) as the wind (change) pushes it away. So, people are hoping, reaching-out for love as the change around them seems to push it ever-farther from grasp. The reaching can, of course, be both physical and non-physical in nature. One can reach-out physically to those near them and one can reach-out via the heart with yearning for, in this case, love. Also, then, people are yearning for love. The heart(s) of the people are yearning for something which seems, in present times, to be just out of reach. I see it as another expression, even a reminder, that as the world grows smaller around us each day, as we have, and are, becoming more separated. With extreme self-indulgence (in "modern" societies) ever apparent today, the modalities used, and the types of interactions had, are inarguably less-connected than the more traditional forms. Of course, any major change has its period of chaos until a majority foothold is once more established, as smaller changes bring about a more comfortable resting place - until the next major social change occurs. I can also see it as, because of the aforementioned 'disconnected-ness', the people are yearning and reaching-out for love and, as change continues to occur, presently seems just out-of-reach, as we move closer together once more, tired of living so close, yet so far from one another. As well, I see simple piece of art which adequately defines a large part of the manifested human experience. Whether it seems to you the balloon is almost within grasp, or just out of, the underlying message is clear: we decide. We decide where change takes us, because we are not limited only to instinct. We decide how we respond to what we see in the world and how we inspire others to see it as well. The world needs free-thinking people that are not subject to social norms to be the change that we want to see. So, yes, the balloon can be both far and near. This is not to speak to the "optimism" and "pessimism" mindsets of categorical understanding which seems to not leave room for the marriage of the two. There exists an understanding that the physical manifestation of this plane of our [physical] existence harbors both light and dark - and that each aspect is resident within us all. What does our expression show the world? How do we respond to the change? How can we influence the change for the better? We decide  Of course, it could also be as simple as a little girl who loved her balloon eventually lost her dear inanimate friend to the wind.

Artworks sold in the EU including the UK within which this auction took place are subject to Artist's Resale Right, whereby when any artwork is resold the artists is entitled to royalties. So that artists who sold work for pennies when they had no name as such can benefit from the success of their work when it later becomes inflated in resales. This isn't the case in the US, but it is worth noting that Artists aren't completely alienated from resales. Furthermore, artists with such an established name as Banksy as you have briefly mentioned can offer authentication of their artworks or even sell them with contracts stipulating image rights and reselling stipulations. So whilst Banksy certainly does have a fraught relationship with the art market he is in many ways more privileged than most artists engaging with the market.

Â @titanium2295Â  If there's one thing I dislike more than people who say that art has to be beautiful and that abstract/conceptual art isn't "real" art, it's when people say that "realistic" art is all surface level and carries no deeper meaning. Traditional painting Ã  la the old masters is often imbued with a ton of symbolism and meaning, and as such invites deeper contemplation of the piece. That said, I don't believe that great art has to have some deep imbued message to be effective. A lot of art simply captures a fleeting moment, a personal experience, something emotional that doesn't ask the viewer to decipher it, only to experience and relate to it. Some of it just tries to convey an emotion through abstract shapes. The point is that I'm a human, and I mainly see art as an expression of the artist's (and/or subject's) humanity, which I can relate to on a deeper level. That's why I would consider Banksy's art more surface level, as it states its whole message outright and the message is the whole experience. A lot of what he's saying with his art has already been said, and with more nuance, in books like 1984 and Brave New World. His pieces can often be summed up with a sentence or two (but that's not necessarily a bad thing, as I will explain).  I don't think that Banksy's art isn't art, and I don't think it's "bad" per se, only that I wouldn't consider it "fine" art worthy of such ridiculous scrutiny, praise, and money, and I would think that Banksy himself would agree considering he has pieces stating things like "I can't believe you morons actually buy this shit". It's very effective graffiti art, and makes good use of straightforward symbolism. He's an incredibly talented "propaganda" artist, but as soon as you put his art in a gallery rather than on the street it loses all its magic.  There's been a lot of goal post moving in these comments, saying that Banksy is "relevant", saying that no other artist is as good at social commentary, asking me to provide examples of artists that I think are better in some specific aspect. My whole point is that these things aren't markers of great art. Art is not propaganda, and its quality should not be measured by how effective it is as such. This is why it feels like people who value this art so highly are neglecting a large part of what makes art "art".   To end, I will state what I thought didn't need to be stated (but apparently does), that this is my opinion. Also, I don't think people are dumb and can't read deeper into art (though I believe many can be quite dismissive of things that aren't immediately clear). All I'm saying is that I'm tired of this kind of simplistic art being lifted up as "genius" when it simply isn't.
